awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  NCS-FO: Flexible Large-Scale Brain Imaging Analysis: Diversity, Individuality and Scalability
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is designed to develop important analysis methods for brain imaging data, provide new educational and outreach activities to help promote the workforce, and create a software tool to foster big data analysis of the human brain. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) enables noninvasive study of brain function, typically through the estimation of functional networks of connectivity. These networks are relatively stable, but it is also clear that there is a wide degree of differences across individuals. Given that now large-scale multi-subject data have now become available across multiple repositories, there is a pressing need for the development of a flexible analysis framework for large-scale fMRI data that can capture the global traits in brain activity, while not losing the individual aspects of a given brain. Such an accurate estimation of each subject's functional connectivity maps enables the leveraging of large and distributed fMRI repositories. It also promises effective comparisons across different conditions, groups, and time points, thus further increasing the usefulness of fMRI in human brain research. The project provides rich educational experience necessary for student training and workforce development in this fast growing field. The benefits are permeated even further via undergraduate research projects and public outreach programs such as brain awareness weeks, in addition to scholarly dissemination through publications, presentations, and workshop organization. The software toolbox developed as part of the project is freely distributed and enables wider adoption and reuse of the methods by the academia and the practitioners to move forward the brain research collectively. Ultimately, the project outcomes contribute to the NSF's mission of promoting the progress of science and advancing the national health, prosperity and welfare.

Data-driven methods based on latent variable models such as independent component analysis (ICA) have been increasingly adopted in fMRI data analysis. Recently, there have been lively debates as to whether ICA leverages source independence, exploits sparsity, or both, igniting active research in sparse matrix models such as dictionary learning (DL) for fMRI analysis. Indeed, synergistically balancing multiple notions of diversity remains an important challenge. In this context, it is first recognized that jointly leveraging both independence and sparsity enables a powerful and flexible framework for analyzing large-scale fMRI data, by capturing the common traits as well as individual details in a data-driven manner. Therefore, the complementary strengths of the already widely used blind source separation approaches such as ICA, and the more recent, sparse matrix factorization models such as DL are advantageously integrated. Essential practical aspects for large-scale data integration studies, such as decentralized computation and privacy-aware sharing of the datasets across multiple repositories are also addressed by leveraging the complementary expertise of the team.

por.por_cntn:
Definition of subspace for capturing individual variability. We introduced two effective models for capturing subject variability in medical imaging analysis studies. The first approach pertains to a general framework for multiset independent subspace analysis, where the subspaces are estimated together with the whole model. This is obviously a challenging task, which limits the probabilistic model that can be used for the underlying latent variables. Another approach we recently introduced first identifies the dimensionality of the model in terms of correlation of the underlying latent variables and splits the datasets into a common (common across all and/or subsets of datasets) and distinct subspace for each. The subspaces are then analyzed separately, providing flexibility in the choice of algorithms for the decomposition, as the problem is now split into more manageable sections. The approach is used for multitask data where we are interested in the joint analysis of only a couple of datasets. We are currently working on extending the method to large-N studies to apply it to large multi-subject fMRI studies.

 Conditions of uniqueness for complex independent vector analysis (IVA). We also derived the conditions for uniqueness of decomposition with IVA when it is implemented in the complex domain. This provides us with additional support for reproducibility of our results for fMRI analysis when IVA is used both for real-valued (magnitude only) and complex-valued (both magnitude and phase) fMRI data. 

Dynamic functional connectivity analysis for capturing individual variability. Dynamic or time-resolved functional connectivity has become an important way to identify individualized variations in a more natural space, given that we know the brain is a highly dynamic organ, and to summarize in ways that allow for statistics which capture individual variability. We investigated such approaches as linking transient states within the default mode network to the individualized measures of behaviors and symptoms, as well as estimating the frequency of the transient states. This continues to be an incredibly rich space and work continues to further unpack the complexity of the human brain.

Privacy-preserving large-scale decentralized analysis of multi-site neuroimaging data. We continued to make contributions in developing approaches to perform privacy preserving and decentralized/federated analysis of neuroimaging data. Our COINSTAC platform (https://github.com/trendscenter/coinstac) provides (to our knowledge) the only approach for performing imaging/voxelwise analysis in a federated framework. We have incorporated multiple pipelines including ICA-based functional connectivity and privacy preserving approaches such as differential privacy and secure multi-party computation. Importantly, we recently performed a large-scale analysis of data from several thousand subjects which was collocated in the US, Europe, and India. We performed a voxel-based morphometry analysis and identified various meaningful results linked to age, body mass index, and smoking. We have also implemented approaches to capture individual variability, including decentralized differentially private classification. 

Broader applications of dictionary and deep learning approaches. We capitalized on the developed learning approaches capturing the commonality and individual variability of data and applied broadly to other problem domains such as the analysis of the mixture radio signals and mammographic image registration. Exploiting the sparsity and approximate orthogonality among the learned features corresponding to different components, DL algorithms that can robustly identify each component signal have been derived. We are currently working to incorporate deep learning methods for even better performance. We also developed deep learningbased registration techniques for multi-view mammography data, where features related to both commonality and discriminability (exploiting lesion annotations) were shown to be instrumental.
